values.description:
Python script to generate cave worlds based on existing tile shapes.  These tile shapes were created in blender and exported to the collada format.

The script handles creating a geometrically-plausible world constructed from the tile shapes, and can optionally place robots in the same world.  Included is a sample robot as well as generated worlds.
values.title: Simple Cave World Generation Scripts

values.description:
A model plugin \(FlashLightPluginBase.cc / hh\) for flash lights attached to a model. Assuming a model has <light> under its <link> components, this plugin modifies the lights based on the given parameters such as color, range, angle, blinking intervals etc.

Users can add their own functionalities by inheriting the class. As an example, the sample code \(SampleFlashLightPlugin.cc\) counts 10 seconds and then turns on the lights. I added a launch file to run it \(flash\_light\_example.launch\).
values.title: Add flash light plugin and sample code

values.description:
**Update \(July 23, 2018\): **`RosFlashLightPlugin` was replaced with `RosLedPlugin`, which can control both light and visual objects. ***This PR depends on FlashLightPlugin/LedPlugin in Gazebo, which will be in the next release. It should be reviewed after then.***

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2763757140-Peek_2018-07-23_10-29.gif)
‌

`RosLedPlugin` to handle <light> and <visual> objects attached on <link> elements** **through ROS service. The service name can be specified by a plugin parameter. If it is given without `/`, the scoped name of the model will be attached as a prefix. In the example, the model name is `light_model`, so lights are toggled by `rosservice call /light_model/light_switch true` and `rosservice call /light_model/light_switch false`.
values.title: Flashlight/LED ROS service plugin

values.description:
This is a minor update on pipelines. It has two updates in the yml file.

* creating /tmp/cpp\_check.suppress  
   Apparently, code\_check.sh skips its job when the temporary file does not exist. It may be necessary to specifically create an empty file so the remote machine automatically runs the code check.
* number of jobs for running tests  
  catkin\_make in default sets the number of jobs to more than one when it runs tests, and it may cause test failure when it runs “catkin\_make run\_tests”.  
   Some of the tests will need to run gzserver, and if I am correct, only one gzserver can run on a machine, leading to conflicts between the tests. So I think it is necessary to explicitly sets it to 1 so each test can run separately. \(or is there any other way?\)

‌
values.title: (minor) update on pipelines

summary.html:
This is a minor update on pipelines. It has two updates in the yml file.

  • creating /tmp/cpp_check.suppress
    Apparently, code_check.sh skips its job when the temporary file does not exist. It may be necessary to specifically create an empty file so the remote machine automatically runs the code check.
  • number of jobs for running tests
    catkin_make in default sets the number of jobs to more than one when it runs tests, and it may cause test failure when it runs “catkin_make run_tests”.
    Some of the tests will need to run gzserver, and if I am correct, only one gzserver can run on a machine, leading to conflicts between the tests. So I think it is necessary to explicitly sets it to 1 so each test can run separately. (or is there any other way?)

values.description:
Rostest examples dynamically generating launch and world files by a python script and yaml files.

I mimicked the testing framework used in ARIAC [[https://bitbucket.org/osrf/ariac/src/master/](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/ariac/src/master/)](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/ariac/src/master). Along with its test node, each rostest file runs a node with python code \(run\_sim.py\) which generates launch and world files based on settings in yaml files dynamically, and finally starts Gazebo simulator.

The original python script \(gear.py\) used in ARIAC is available at [https://bitbucket.org/osrf/ariac/src/master/osrf\_gear/script/gear.py](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/ariac/src/master/osrf_gear/script/gear.py), which is also used for their competition. It converts template files \(i.e., gear.launch.template, gear.world.template, etc\) into actual launch and world files by empy based on parameters given in arguments and yaml files. In the python script of this PR, the parts specific to ARIAC were removed.

There are two rostest examples. Both of them just set up ros and gazebo transport node and exit, but the first one generates a world file while the second uses an existing world file specified in the arguments. Most of parameters in yaml files are just for example, and they don’t do anything.

In stead of the template world file, I guess it is also possible to generate a random tunnel world by calling another python script in run\_sim.py.

I appreciate any comments and advice!
values.title: Rostest examples configurable by python and yaml

values.reason: This PR is declined. This approach generates launch and world files in runtime, but it was not necessary as far as a world file is generated in configuration time.

values.description:
This is not a critical issue, but when the Indian tunnel is loaded, the following warning appears.  
**Warning \[**[**parser.cc:626**](http://parser.cc:626)**\] Can not find the XML attribute 'version' in sdf XML tag for model: indian\_tunnel. Please specify the SDF protocol supported in the model configuration file. The first sdf tag in the config file will be used**

This was because I wrote the config and sdf files incorrectly \(sorry!\) and <sdf> tag in the config does not specify the version of sdf file used for the model. The message disappears after these files are updated.
values.title: Hotfix on parser warning of Indian tunnel config and sdf

summary.html:
This is not a critical issue, but when the Indian tunnel is loaded, the following warning appears.
Warning [parser.cc:626] Can not find the XML attribute 'version' in sdf XML tag for model: indian_tunnel. Please specify the SDF protocol supported in the model configuration file. The first sdf tag in the config file will be used

This was because I wrote the config and sdf files incorrectly (sorry!) and <sdf> tag in the config does not specify the version of sdf file used for the model. The message disappears after these files are updated.

values.description:
Sample deployment of a team of Jackal, Husky, and Iris into a cave environment

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3594140239-example.jpg)
![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/418104792-Peek_2018-08-14_15-53-2.gif)
‌

`team.launch` spawns a team of Jackal, Husky, and Iris, equipped with lights. A user can control them by either a gamepad or keyboard. The designs of the lights and dispositions are just for demonstration and to be redesigned.

**URDF**

* Added `urdf/xacro` files for flashlight and LED models \(in `subt_gazebo`\)
* Added `husky_equipments.urdf.xacro`, `jackal_equipments.urdf.xacro`, `iris_equipments.urdf.xacro` defining how a robot holds the lights
* Added revised versions of `husky.urdf.xacro` and `jackal.urdf.xacro`, so as to include the files above and to deploy multiple robots.

**Updated subt\_example\_node**

It has the following features now.

* Teleop: listens to topics advertised by joy stick/keyboard teleop
* Communication: uses CommsClient to send a message to another robot. Both sender and receivers flash their center LED.
* Flashlights: publishes ROS messages to control its flashlights.
* Control of a robot: publishes ROS message to each robot `cmd_vel` topic
* Selection: while being selected by the teleop, it blinks its left and right LEDs.

**Teleop by the keyboard**

Type:  
 `rosrun subt_example teleop_twist_keyboard.py`

It is almost the same as the original teleop script, but it displays a list of robots and you can choose a robot to control by hitting the corresponding number keys \(1-9 and 0\). The keys `a` and `s` turn the lights on and off, respectively. The script loads a yaml file `config/robot_config.yaml` containing a list of robot names. When you hit a number key while pressing down a shift key, the currently selected robot sends a message to the robot with the corresponding number.

**Teleop by the \(logitech\) joy stick**

Config data is in `config/logitech_config.yaml`

* To move robots: hold the left button \(LB\) and use the left joy stick to go forward/backward and turn.
* To use the turbo mode: hold the right button \(RB\) and use the same joy stick.
* For Iris, use the right joy stick to move vertically \(z-axis\) and horizontally \(y-axis\).
* To turn the lights on/off: use the left trigger \(LT\) / right trigger \(RT\).
* To select the robot: press A, B, X, or Y button \(the key bindings are defined in `config/robot_config.yaml`\).
* To send a message: press an arrow key

**lava\_tube.world**

To make the environment to look more realistic \(and just for fun\)

* Removed the sun
* Added the color of the cave in model.sdf
values.title: Teleop of a team of Jackal, Husky, and Iris (in a dark lava tube)

To capture task time. Some details that will change in the future:

* The gates are mainly for testing purposes. They will probably change for something else.
* The `ContainPlugin` are hard-coded for Husky, Jackal and Iris robots. We need to modify the plugin to support the ability to trigger the messages when any object crosses the gate.
* For now, we’re only tracking elapsed time. We’ll add more elements when further scoring details are known.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/900312804-subt_scoring.gif)

values.description:
## Random world generation

1. Install Ruby:

        sudo apt-get install ruby2.5 ruby2.5-dev

1. Go to the worlds directory

        cd  subt_gazebo/worlds

1. Run erb to generate a random world with default params

        erb tile.world.erb > cave.world
 
1. Try different options, such as `n=3` to generate a 3x3 world:

        erb n=3 tile.world.erb > cave_3x3.world

1. ... or s=100 to set the random seed

        erb s=100 tile.world.erb > cave_s100.world

1. In the future, the same script could be used for mines as long as the meshes follow the same naming scheme

Randomly generated and committed cave world:

![Screenshot from 2018-08-09 17-55-43.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/1886489238-Screenshot_from_2018-08-09_17-55-43.png)

## Cave world

* I'm not using the `cave_tile_ramp` yet, which will need logic for adding new "storeys"
* I didn't add the game logic plugin or the gates because those seem to be very specific to the lava tube for now

## Launch

* Substituted `lava_tube.launch` with `competition.launch`, which loads the lava tube by default, for example:

        roslaunch subt_gazebo competition.launch

* Other worlds can be used by setting the `scenario` argument, for example, to use the cave world:

        roslaunch subt_gazebo competition.launch scenario:=cave

* Also adapted the `subt_example` launch files to use this. So by default they still do what they used to (`lava_tube`), but you can pass `scenario` to override it, for example:

        roslaunch subt_example jackal.launch scenario:=cave

    ![jackalstart.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/1334431747-jackalstart.png)

    or

        roslaunch subt_example iris.launch scenario:=cave

    ![irisstart.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3585875739-irisstart.png)

    or 

        roslaunch subt_example husky.launch scenario:=cave

    ![huskystart.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/1809813129-huskystart.png)

## Updates 1b43c62

* Outside staging area
* Using the pre-existing cave entrance as a placeholder for now
* Scaled blockers so they cover the whole exit
* Support rectangular layouts for longer caves
* Outside lighting

![cave_5.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/199001242-cave_5.png)
![cave_6.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3936076220-cave_6.png)
values.title: Randomized cave tiles

values.description:
The next iteration of the scoring plugin. I worked with the assumption that we’ll tweak a lot of things when we have more information about the objects of interest, points, etc.

* The `GameLogicPlugin` accepts `<object_of_interest>` tags, where can specify the name of the model. The plugin, parses all these objects and stores them for scoring purposes.
* The teams can call the ROS service call `/subt/object_of_interest/new` and provide the location of the object.
* The plugin iterates through the list of stored objects and finds out which is the closest object to the one reported from the team request. Then, the score is based on the comparison between this real object and the reported from the team.
* The score uses Euclidean distance \(the lower value the better\) and time \(the sooner the better\) to calculate the score.
* After invoking this ROS service call, the object of interest store in memory is deleted.
* A topic `/subt/score` has been created where the total score is periodically published.
values.title: Score v2

values.description:
Updated GameLogicPlugin: the team can start the game \(or scoring\) by letting arbitrary objects enter a specified starting area, and stop the game by calling a ROS service.

The original GameLogicPlugin needed a ContainPlugin for each robot to initiate/finish the game. Since the environment is now supposed to have a single entrance to the subterranean space and no exit, the updated plugin accepts any object entering a designated start area and a ROS service call to end the game.

‌

**Start:**

A designated start area is represented by a collision object whose `<collision_without_contact>` is set to 1 so it does not cause any physical intervention. The plugin subscribes `~/physics/contains` topic and checks if the collision object got a collision with an object.

The example specifies the area under the gate as the starting area. The game starts when any kind of object enters the space.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/700136313-Peek_2018-08-20_12-29.gif)
‌

The following example shows spawning a box in the start area. Once it is spawned, it detects a collision leading to starting the game.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/1498692513-Peek_2018-08-20_12-31.gif)
‌

**Finish:**

When a team calls the ROS service `/subt/finish`, the game is done and the elapsed time is reported.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/264940761-Peek_2018-08-20_12-30.gif)
‌

**The cave entrance:**

Here is an example in `cave.world`. The starting area is highlighted with orange color.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/4145597650-Peek_2018-08-20_17-44.gif)
values.title: New start gate and ROS service to finish the game

It has four controllable headlights and multiple LEDs in the back and both sides.

values.description:
* Initial mine \(hand-made\)
* Seven different tiles
* Not all the tiles have entries/exits in every edge, so it’s not trivial to integrate it in the cave script. Note that when there’s no tunnel in one edge, there’s disc blocking a potential incoming entry \(this will be handy if we integrate these tiles into the world generator script\).
* Added simple collision elements to the ground of each tile

For testing:

    roslaunch subt_gazebo competition.launch scenario:=mine_practice_1

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/1419797111-mine.png)
‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/856455305-mine_collisions.png)
‌

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3519753344-mine_inside.png)
values.title: Practice mine 1

values.description:
Integration of the communication model. This pull request extends the current `comms_broker_plugin` to support:

* Query the list of neighbors that are under my range of communication.
* Specify the minimum and maximum distance to communicate between a pair of robots.
* Specify the minimum and maximum distance to detect neighbors.
* Set a minimum and maximum probability of dropping a message.
* Set the probability of entering into an outage.
* Set the minimum and maximum duration of an outage.
* A maximum communication data rate.

I've disabled the `comms_test` for now until I have extra time to work on a proper way to test these features.

In order to test this pull request you'll need to play with the `<comms_model>` parameters and use the joystick to send messages to other robots. You can use the left, right, up, down buttons to send a message from the selected robot to any of the others. You should see that the back LED blinks twice if the message is received.
values.title: Comms model

values.description:
Added the ability to load X2 with four sensor configurations:

1. 2D short range LIDAR \+ QVGA camera \+ IMU
2. 2D short range LIDAR \+ HD camera \+ IMU
3. 2D medium range LIDAR \+ QVGA camera \+ IMU
4. 2D medium range LIDAR \+ HD camera \+ IMU

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/2675006934-x2_low.png)
![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/907108141-x2_med.png)
For now, the configuration is done via environment variables.

For testing, use `X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1`, `X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_2`, `X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_3` or `X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_4`. Here’s an example:

    roslaunch subt_gazebo competition.launch scenario:=tunnel_practice_2
    X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_3=1 roslaunch subt_example team.launch

‌

_~~Note: This pull request is built atop pull request #48, which should be merged first.~~_

  1. 2D short range LIDAR + QVGA camera + IMU
  2. 2D short range LIDAR + HD camera + IMU
  3. 2D medium range LIDAR + QVGA camera + IMU
  4. 2D medium range LIDAR + HD camera + IMU

For now, the configuration is done via environment variables.

For testing, use X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_1, X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_2, X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_3 or X2_SENSOR_CONFIG_4. Here’s an example:

roslaunch subt_gazebo competition.launch scenario:=tunnel_practice_2
